Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: I woke up early, the scent of sawdust still clinging to my clothes from yesterday’s job. As I passed the kitchen, I saw my parents sitting quietly, their faces drawn and tired. Lately, they seemed weighed down by something unspoken, and I felt the familiar tug of worry. I wanted to sit with them, to ask what was wrong, to be the support they needed. But my phone buzzed—a homeowner’s message, urgent: the deck was splintered and unsafe, and they needed it fixed today. My mind raced with the expectation to be reliable, to show up and do the work right. Yet, as I gathered my tools, I kept glancing back at my parents, guilt gnawing at me. I was torn between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my craft. The pressure built inside me, each role demanding more than I felt I could give. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, heart pounding, unsure which door to walk through.
